results.abstract: Anticipated confirmation of US Sen W B Saxbe as US Atty Gen is seen presenting variety of options for Ohio Gov J J Gilligan, Dem, and producing major headache for Ohio Repub party; leading option for Gilligan would be to select as Saxbe's successor someone who would receive backing of state Dem orgn in '74 Sen race--presumably H M Metzenbaum, Cleveland millionaire-businessman; J H Glenn Jr, former astronaut and another leading Ohio Dem, has been all but ruled out because of his attack on Gilligan and state party last mo in which he accused them of 'bossism' and 'blackmail' in attempting to arrange Sen endorsement for Metzenbaum; another option would be apptmt of 'caretaker' Sen who would retire at end of Saxbe's term in '74 and not seek office for himself; names of potential caretakers being mentioned by Ohio Dems include F W King, Ohio AFL-CIO pres, and M V DiSalle, lawyer

headline.main: Picking a Saxbe Successor Up to Gilligan, a Democrat; 74 Campaigning Sought

results.snippet: Confirmation of William B. Saxbe as United States Attorney General would present a variety of options for Ohio Gov. John J. Gilligan, a Democrat, and produce a major headache for the Ohio Republican party.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Confirmation of William B. Saxbe as United States Attorney General would present a variety of options for Ohio Gov. John J. Gilligan, a Democrat, and produce a major headache for the Ohio Republican party.

results.abstract: NASA officials remain optimistic on Nov 10 that 3d and final Skylab mission can be launched on Thursday despite temporary slowdown in efforts of technicians to replace corroded and cracked stabilizing fins of Saturn 1-B rocket; are expected to imminently decide whether launching deadline is realistic or if additional 5-day delay must be ordered

headline.main: SKYLAB'S REPAIRS BEHIND SCHEDULE; Launching Decision Due Susceptible to Corrosion But Aides Remain Hopeful About Thursday Launching

results.snippet: Work to replace defective tall fins on the Saturn rocket for Skylab 3 continued to run behind schedule today, but space officials remained hopeful that the mission could be launched next Thursday.

byline.original: Special to The New York TimesBy JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

results.lead_paragraph: Work to replace defective tall fins on the Saturn rocket for Skylab 3 continued to run behind schedule today, but space officials remained hopeful that the mission could be launched next Thursday.

headline.main: Mission's Civilian Scientist in Residence; Edward George Gibson Two Men Resigned Admiration Expressed Born in Buffalo

results.snippet: To Edward George Gibson, the 37-year-old civilian scientist-astronaut and author of a book called "The Quiet Sun," the chance to spend eight weeks or more aboard Skylab, operating an array of solar telescopes, is "the opportunity of a lifetime."

headline.main: A Veteran Pilot With a Penchant for Math; William Reid Pogue Commission in 1952 Became an Instructor

results.lead_paragraph: Before he went aloft on his first space flight for eight or more weeks as the commander of the Skylab 3 crew, Gerald Paul Carr, a close-cropped lieutenant colonel in the Marine Corps, said exuberantly, "I'm looking forward most to sticking my nose up against the wardroom

results.abstract: 3d and final Skylab mission is launched from Cape Canaveral at 9.01 AM on Nov 16 after 6-day delay caused by discovery of cracks and corrosion in stabilizing fins of Saturn 1-B rocket; 8 hrs after launch crew members, Lt Col G P Carr, Lt Col W R Pogue and Dr E G Gibson, dock Apollo command module with orbiting laboratory 270 mi above earth; Pres Nixon lauds mission; crew repts Col Pogue is suffering from nausea but that they are making 'an over-all satisfactory adjustment to zero gravity'; experiments, which will be performed by crew revd; launching described; crew illus at breakfast prior to launching; Saturn rocket illus leaving launching pad at Cape Canaveral

headline.main: Skylab 3 Crew Docks With Lab in Orbit As Astronauts Begin 84-Day Mission; Repaired Saturn Rocket Launched Smoothly Astronauts Dock With Lab As 84-Day Mission Begins Comet Observations Three Rookies in Space A Tense Moment

results.snippet: Three American astronauts were launched here today on the nation's last manned space flight for at least a year and a half, a planned 84-day mission aboard the earth-orbiting Skylab space station.

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORDSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Three American astronauts were launched here today on the nation's last manned space flight for at least a year and a half, a planned 84-day mission aboard the earth-orbiting Skylab space station.

headline.main: Skylab 3 Crew Docks With Lab in Orbit As Astronauts Begin 84-Day Mission; Repaired Saturn Rocket Launched Smoothly Astronauts Dock With Lab As 84-Day Mission Begins Comet Observations Three Rookies in Space A Tense Moment

results.snippet: Three American astro nauts were launched here today on the nation's last manned space flight for at least a year and a half, a planned 84-day mission aboard the earth-orbiting Skylab space station.

results.abstract: Lt Col W R Pogue, Lt Col G P Carr and Dr E G Gibson, crew members aboard 3d Skylab mission, on Nov 17 move from Apollo command module into Skylab space station 13 hrs ahead of schedule and activate onboard systems, but are reprimanded for withholding med information about Col Pogue, who was experiencing nausea; are upbraided for committing 'a fairly serious error in judgment' for failing to inform NASA physicians that Pogue had vomited once; NASA officials reptdly learned of astronauts' attempt to conceal true med condition of Pogue from tape-recorded conversations that were radioed automatically to mission control; astronauts apparently were unaware that tape recorder was running at time they discussed Pogue's condition; conversation detailed; NASA physicians rept astronauts are continuing to take anti-motion sickness medication, and that while Carr and Pogue are experiencing 'stomach awareness' Gibson appears to be in excellent health

headline.main: Skylab Astronauts Are Reprimanded In 1st Day Aboard; Learned from Tape SKYLAB 3'S CREW GETS REPRIMAND

results.snippet: A serious reprimand from Mission Control marred the Skylab 3 astronauts' first day aboard their earth-orbiting space station.

byline.original: Special to The New York TimesBy JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

results.lead_paragraph: A serious reprimand from Mission Control marred the Skylab 3 astronauts' first day aboard their earth-orbiting space station.

results.abstract: K Kennedy, eldest daughter of late Sen R F Kennedy, is married on Nov 17 to D L Townsend; Sen E Kennedy escorts his niece; guests include ex-astronaut J Glenn, F Mankiewicz, Sen and Mrs G McGovern, columnist A Buchwald and singer A Williams; Pres Kennedy's wife does not attend; bride's attendants noted; ushers listed; other guests noted; wedding and reception described; illus of bride and Sen Kennedy, of bride and groom and of Kennedy family at ceremony

headline.main: Wedding Ceremony Brings Happier Moment to Kennedy Family; Well-Known Guests Six Nonfamily Bridesmaids Replica of a Raft

results.snippet: Kathleen Kennedy, the eldest of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy's children, was married today to David Lee Townsend, a Harvard graduate student, in a ceremony slightly dimmed by yet another family tragedy but ebullient enough to include the...

byline.original: By LINDA CHARLTONSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Kathleen Kennedy, the eldest of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy's children, was married today to David Lee Townsend, a Harvard graduate student, in a ceremony slightly dimmed by yet another family tragedy but ebullient enough to include the singing of "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling."

results.abstract: crew members aboard 3d Skylab mission on Nov 18 perform variety of chores in effort to regain time lost because of 6-day delay in launching and their bout with motion sickness shortly after entering space station; work to move several hundred pounds of equipment from Apollo command module into Skylab, and begin series of med experiments that may provide new data about effects of long-term missions in space; astronaut Dr E G Gibson takes blood samples from himself and other crew members and processes samples for later study by NASA physicians; NASA flight controller repts several procedural errors' by astronauts during activation of space station caused minor problems; says astronauts turned on wrong switch, dumping overboard antiseptic solution that was supposed to sterilize their water system, and that incorrectly set switches led to delay in testing of ventilation system and of on-board TV system

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS TRY TO MAKE UP TIME; Skylab 3 Lehind Schedule as Result of Sickness Error Reported Astronauts In Moscow

results.snippet: Scrambling to get back on schedule today the Skylab 3 astronauts sorted out and stowed thousands of items they will need for their three months aboard the orbiting space station.
results.lead_paragraph: Scrambling to get back on schedule today the Skylab 3 astronauts sorted out and stowed thousands of items they will need for their three months aboard the orbiting space station.

results.abstract: Brig Gen T P Stafford and D K Slayton, US astronauts, begin 2-wk training session with Soviet crews on Nov 19 at Zvezdny Gorodok, USSR, in preparation for joint US-USSR space mission in '75 during which crews of Apollo and Suyoz spacecraft will dock in earth orbit and exchange crews; Stafford illus with Maj Gen V A Shatalov, chief of Soviet astronaut training, and Maj Gen G T Beregovoi

headline.main: U.S. Astronauts in Soviet To Train With Russians; Crews Introduced Difference of Opinion

results.snippet: "Which way is north?" asked Brig. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, American commander for the joint Soviet-American space mission set for July, 1975.

byline.original: By HEDRICK SMITHSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: "Which way is north?" asked Brig. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, American commander for the joint Soviet-American space mission set for July, 1975.

results.abstract: Lt Col W R Pogue, crew member aboard 3d Skylab mission, on Nov 19 successfully replenishes space station's cooling system with fresh supply of fluid after series of delays caused by faulty repair equipment; discovered pressure leaks in hose feeding cooling fluid from tank into system through special valve

headline.main: Astronaut Overcomes a Snag While Repairing Cooling Lines; Fresh Supply of Fluid More Space Dust Found

results.snippet: Lieut. Col. William R. Pogue of the Air Force successfully filled the Skylab's vital equipment cooling 'system with a fresh supply of fluid today after a series of delays caused by faulty repair equipment

results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet note that led to a precautionary alert of United States forces around the world on the night of Oct. 24 carried an implied threat rather than an actual threat of the dispatch of Soviet troops to the Suez war zone.

results.abstract: Dr E G Gibson, crew member aboard 3d Skylab mission, repts on Nov 20 that lack of gravity within laboratory has disoriented crew and has even made tying shoelaces a chore; repts it is sometimes difficult to recognize where he is and that crew has to consciously think about gravity; Lt Col Carr and Pogue perform med tests to determine whether they are fit to perform 'space walk' on Thanksgiving Day

headline.main: Astronaut Reports on Weightlessness; Familiar Attitude

results.snippet: Edward G. Gibson, Skylab 3 astronaut-scientist, said today that lack of gravity in the eight-room space vehicle had disoriented the crew and even made tying shoelaces a chore.
results.lead_paragraph: Edward G. Gibson, Skylab 3 astronaut-scientist, said today that lack of gravity in the eight-room space vehicle had disoriented the crew and even made tying shoelaces a chore.

results.abstract: Article discusses career of Col B McCandless 2d, 'one of the forgotten astronauts, the men left waiting after all the seats on the planned US space flights were filled'; McCandless is optimistic that future role as US astronaut may be realized when nation proceeds with space shuttle program

headline.main: Rookie Astronaut Sees Chance in Space Shuttle

results.snippet: He sits in a padded swivel chair confronted by winking lights and flicking digital clocks, a rookie who never got a mission, the Mission Control console his closest approach to space.

results.abstract: expansion of Indian-USSR econ cooperation is one goal USSR party leader Brezhnev and Premier Gandhi seek during Brezhnev's visit to India

headline.main: BREZHNEV ARRIVES IN INDIA FOR TALKS; Moscow's Major Economic Role to Be DiscussedBig Welcome Given Support Drummed Up Retinue Is Large Soviet Signed Treaty

results.snippet: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, was exuberantly welcomed to New Delhi today to begin talks on the shape of Moscow's relationship with India.

byline.original: By BERNARD WEINRAUBSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, was exuberantly welcomed to New Delhi today to begin talks on the shape of Moscow's relationship with India.

results.abstract: USSR astronaut training chief Maj Gen V A Shatalov discloses on Nov 29 that USSR plans more manned Soyuz space flights-both individual missions and linkups of Soyuz with Salyut space station--before joint US-USSR mission in '75, news conf, Zvezdny Gorodok, winding up 2 wks of joint training of US and USSR crews for '75 mission; US crew comdr Brig Gen T P Stafford says he is completely satisfied that Soyuz is 'great' spacecraft; US astronaut training chief D K Slayton comments; US astronauts laud hospitality they recd in USSR; say they detected number of differences between actual Soyuz craft and ground simulators; Capt A L Bean, comdr of backup crew, says USSR and US space food is similar; mission plan calls for at least 1 USSR and 1 US astronaut to move into other nation's spacecraft while 2 are docked; US astronauts say good rapport was estab with Soviet crew; Gagarin Training Center chief Maj Gen G T Beregovoi holds there have been language problems; he and others caution that astronauts will not be allowed to be accompanied by interpreters in flight simulators during next stage of training; he contends they will have to master much more tech language; US astronauts rept they found Soyuz craft to be similar to older US 2-man Gemini spacecraft and not quite as sophisticated as Apollo craft; note Soyuz was designed largely for earth orbital mission whereas Apollo was designed for moon flights; Stafford repts that 2 sides have agreed to hold 2 joint training sessions in '74--one in USSR in July and other at Manned Spacecraft Center, Houston, in Sept

headline.main: SOVIET PLANNING MORE SPACE SHOTS; Disclosure Is Made as U.S. and Russian Crews Praise Training for '75 Link-Up Space Snack on Earth Soviet Food Rations

results.snippet: A senior Soviet space official disclosed plans today for more Soviet manned space flights--individual Soyuz missions and link-ups of the Soyuz with the Salyut orbital platform--before the joint Soviet-American space mission in 1975.

byline.original: By HEDRICK SMITHSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A senior Soviet space official disclosed plans today for more Soviet manned space flights--individual Soyuz missions and link-ups of the Soyuz with the Salyut orbital platform--before the joint Soviet-American space mission in 1975.
